instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW: What is SMC_BATLOW? SMC_BATLOW refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message:
This macbook was dropped by the owner; it has a green magsafe but wont power on. no fan spin
Measurements:

S5 rails are present, S3 and up aren't

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - present

<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW</SIGNAL> - 0V, no pulse when shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and not shorted
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - present

<SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V.

Unless I'm mistaken here, <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> requires <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW</SIGNAL> to be present before it'll put out <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>

If thats right, then what is required for <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW</SIGNAL> to be generated by the SMC? I'm thinking the SMC cracked a trace/ball during the fall but I'd like to be more certain (if possible) before replacing the damn thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message:
Dropped machine is a nightmare always.
Missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW</SIGNAL> can be sign of incorrect charger; be sure to use original 85W one.
In your case I think about broken trace/solder under SMC, or PCH.

Test all RTC signals (page 16) and also check basic signals for System Power Management (page 17).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message:
Shitbrain at work here... I was using a 60 watt charger. Doh.. This thing has been at another repair guy, it came with <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> missing from the board. I replaced those and then did the testing with the wrong adapter... With the right adapter, its working almost fine. Dont know why the other repair guy took the IC's off.

Two issues remained: cardreader didnt work because of a broken trace in the board somewhere, fixed that with a jumper.
There was a crack in the board at one USB port. I fixed all connections across the break with jumpers, making it work normally with usb 2 sticks.
However, USB 3 sticks are not detected most of the time and dont work properly when they are detected. I went over the cracked connections three times now, but everything is in order. I followed the rails across the board and found no problem, but cant check whats under the PCH.
The other port is functional with usb 3 sticks, but the macbook will hang on a black screen if left on for a little while. When booting from internal drive, this doesnt happen..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message:
Which USB port doesn't work at all (as USB3)?
Check the small coils and capacitors corresponding to USB3 data lines (USB3_EXTx_).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message: Port B (J4700) wont work with usb 3. I've already done the coils, will see if I can find anything else on those rails tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message: Compare diode mode to ground on data lines with working board; or at least with the other port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message:
Made an error in my previous reply; Port B (bad one) is J4600

Think I found it...

<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTA_TX_P</SIGNAL> = 41.4kOhm / 0.352 diode
<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTA_TX_N</SIGNAL> = 41.4kOhm / 0.352 diode

<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_TX_P</SIGNAL> = 0L / 0L diode
<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_TX_N</SIGNAL> = 0L / 0L diode

These all go right to the PCH. So, either cracked balls under PCH or broken traces in the board. I dont see any test points or other spots these lines go to, so no way to jumper. As is this is near a crack on the board, I dont think its the PCH. Its actually operating stable from internal drive, so semi-fixed. Anything else to do before I call this one finished?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
threads.message: If one port still works as USB 3.0 recommend an external USB 3.0 hub to the client...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no power, green magsafe.
